awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A platform for simulating the combined effect of human behavior and environment on airborne infectious spread (COVID-19)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to minimize infection by contagious diseases, such as COVID-19. This project advances a cloud-based platform for simulating particle flow in heavily populated, dynamic environments.  It will enable facility managers and health/ safety stakeholders to simulate viral particle dispersion in  indoor environments for design and mitigation procedures (disinfection, evacuation, etc.). This technology can play a role in mitigating the ongoing effects of the current COVID-19 pandemic and better prepare facilities for the next pandemic. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project supports facility planning and response of infectious disease outbreaks. The project advances a hybrid computational approach to utilizing multi-scale fluid analysis for faster-than-real-time multimodal simulation. The research objectives are to: (1) create a simulation platform that can parallelize equations and perform at near real-time or real-time, which will provide a means to simulate multimodal interactions in real buildings, such as contamination spread in fluid flow, when analyzed with human behavior and mobility; (2) characterize and validate the results of the simulator by measuring particle spread in multiple real building scenarios. It is anticipated that the simulation results of particle trajectory and surface contamination will be at least as accurate as state-of-the-art high-fidelity computational fluid dynamic techniques, but delivered in real time. This project will provide an environment and behavior-specific simulation essential for optimizing airflow and facility controls to reducing airborne infectious transmission.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary

Intelligent Medicine's Phase I SBIR accomplishments have led to the creation of a real-time, multiscale physics framework for viral particle transmission in indoor environments. When utilized within the healthcare facility setting, this innovation is intended to reduce infectious spread and improve occupant health. It accomplishes this by providing facility and clinical stakeholders with the ability to simulate viral particle dispersion in populated, indoor environments to better design facilities and plan circumstance-specific mitigation procedures (disinfection, evacuation, etc.) The development of this platform took place in 3 parts.

The first part was the development of real-time, computational fluid dynamic (CFD) algorithms which emphasized multi-physics interactions between indoor environments and human occupants. The goal for this part was to simulate the effects that buildings occupants would have on the particle flow within real environments to predict infectious risk transmission. To accomplish this, we developed a GPU-based, multiscale algorithm based on the Navier-Stokes equations and tested our computational results against proven CFD algorithms. The benefits of our algorithms are the real-time component (traditional algorithms can take hours to days) and scalability based on changing environments.

Part two included the development of realistic human behaviors within simulated environments. The goal for this part was to generate occupant pathing and actions which may influence particle transmission and are representative of the spaces being modeled. To accomplish this, we developed behavioral algorithms using probabilistic behavior trees combined with an A* (A-star) pathfinding on standardized building information models (BIM). The developed human behaviors allowed for the generation of occupant pathing and interactions within the simulation through facility census and occupancy data.

Finally, we tested our platform through an in-situ case study at a healthcare facility. This included first simulating and then performing bioburden measurements within a Behavioral clinic dispensing area under two different conditions: 1) normal heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) and 2) during a mechanical failure with no airflow. The goal for this study was to determine the effect that no airflow within a space would have on particle transport, and therefore infectious risk, to come up with backup alternatives for maintaining a high standard of environmental quality and validate the accuracy of our simulated results. Ultimately, what we found in the absence of HVAC, particles would not travel as far, and would transmit between occupants if not enough time lapsed for the particles to settle. Statistically, we observed strong correlations between the simulator and multiple air sampling devices (up to r=0.82). Additionally, when performing a two-sample t-test between the simulated particles and actual counts by two devices (Mattson-Garvin 220 Air Sampler and SAS Super 180 Microbial Air Sampler), the results were not significantly (p<.05) different on multiple days.

Next steps

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the dire consequences of airborne transmitted diseases, with estimated financial impacts to the US healthcare industry of around $323 billion in 2020 alone. By improving our healthcare facility's ability to respond, we can reduce the risk of infectious transmission and better prepare for potential future outbreaks. This innovation has demonstrated the utility for predicting viral transmission when designing and controlling healthcare facilities and beyond. The developed framework has been integrated into Intelligent Medicine's beachhead product, Circulate, which is being proposed as a facility analytics tool for improving health, safety, and well-being. Early adopters have used Circulate for analysis and design, while expressing interest toward receiving continuous feedback based on their facility's current state. Within the healthcare facility setting, Circulate looks to provide real-time bioburden monitoring and control based on the HVAC, environment, and occupancy sensors. Utilization of the developed framework is also being explored collaboratively for use in 1) autonomous disinfection, 2) improving product quality control, and 3) decarbonizing space cooling and heating in buildings.
